webTitle: School of stock: who cares where FTSE 100 bosses were educated?

fields.standfirst: A rundown of chief executives' alma maters is instructive. But its authors are focusing on the wrong area of inequality
fields.body:
Here's an exam question for you. FTSE 100 chief executives are split equally between those educated privately and those who went to a state school. A new government imposes a radical system compelling companies to fill 70% of boardroom vacancies with state-educated candidates. Assuming 10 chief executives leave every year, how long does it take to get to the point where 70% of FTSE 100 bosses are from the state sector?

The answer – after a lot of other assumptions – is a decade. This is instructive, as a consultancy called Equal Approach is bemoaning the "slow progress" of changing the status quo, in which 45% of FTSE 100 chief executives and chairs were schooled privately in the UK, while 28% studied at Oxbridge.

Even so, it is hard to see a reason to moan on this topic. The kiwi Ross McEwan has just got the top job at Royal Bank of Scotland, while Mark Selway, an Australian, has bagged the vacancy at the engineering group IMI.

Of the newly installed Brits, the BT Group boss, Gavin Patterson, went to Cambridge but also to a comprehensive school.

What a thoughtful pupil may notice, however, is that the FTSE is dominated by white, middle-aged men. In the study of diversity, schooling is not the main question.

webTitle: Investors in two biggest UK-listed energy firms should be wary

fields.bodyText: Investors in the two largest UK-listed energy businesses are wrapped in a financial duvet this winter. While the share prices in Centrica and SSE may have dipped last week on the back of Ed Miliband's threat of a price freeze, they are well ahead of their 2009 level. Centrica's share price is up by more than half at 367p. SSE stood at £10.60 in early 2009 and closed at £14.74 on Monday. Then there are the ever-rising dividends. Without any interruption for the financial crash, SSE's shareholder payout has climbed from 26.4p a share in 2004 to 56.1p last year. On Monday SSE pledged to maintain its generous payout despite predicting that first-half profits would be lower than analysts' expectations. How can it insulate investors in this way? We only need to look back to May when it warned consumers to brace themselves for further price rises. No wonder Miliband blasted the industry. Until now it has proved immune to criticism that it siphons consumer cash and deposits it in the bank accounts of investors. Even SSE's defence that it will maintain a £1.5bn investment programme rings hollow when the risks attached to that investment are near zero. It plans to build wind farms near its Scottish base with a guarantee from the government of a premium rate for the electricity. Then there is the upgrade of the grid. The regulator insists on a five-year programme. This is the only real cost for inheriting the infrastructure at a knockdown cost. Yet investors should be wary. They could be left exposed like the shareholders in EDF, RWE and E.ON who have suffered 80% share price falls since 2008 following tough government action in their home markets for France and Germany. A future British government may follow suit.

webTitle: Loans for small businesses is where George Osborne really needs to focus

fields.standfirst: The chancellor has brought forward the Help To Buy scheme. If only he had spared a thought for the small-business sector
fields.body:
George Osborne is desperate to inject ever more life into the housing market, bringing forward the second stage of the government's Help to Buy scheme to encourage mortgage lenders to pump more credit into home loans.

But the chancellor seems to have been distracted from any parallel efforts to breathe life into the small business sector, which five years on from the financial crisis is still feeling neglected.

Data from the Bank of England published on Monday showed mortgage approvals at their highest levels since February 2008 – but also showed lending to businesses fell by £3.8bn in August, in the sharpest drop since last December.

As Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight puts it, this is "a blow to hopes that lending to business is starting to pick up after a rare increase of £466m in July".

Within the small- and medium-sized (SME) sector, lending fell by £678m in August after an £893m drop the month before. These decreases come despite the funding-for-lending scheme (FLS): cheap money for banks that was supposed to make it easier for lenders to pass on cheaper loans to businesses and households.

The FLS may have stopped credit being sucked out of the economy as quickly as it was in the immediate aftermath of the crisis, but it has failed, so far, to inject any extra fuel into the small businesses – the businesses that account for six in every 10 jobs in the private sector.

There is less lending than in the past to the commercial property sector, which at times accounted for as much as 40% of lending. This could help account for the declines, but business groups say more could be done. The British Chambers of Commerce put it most succinctly, using the latest figures to declare: "Britain's business finance system remains broken."

webTitle: Looming US shutdown and Italian political turmoil hits markets - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
New US Shutdown Liveblog Here
• Closing Summary - key events
• Latest: Berlusconi faces revolt?
• How Letta's government could survive
• Greek deputy PM rules out early elections
fields.body:
6.57pm BST

Time to shut up here. For full rolling coverage of the US Federal government shutdown, do stay tuned to our US liveblog:

US government shutdown: White House decries Republican 'extortion' – live

I'll be back tomorrow to cover all the reaction to whatever happens in America tonight, along with key events in the UK and Europe. Until then, goodnight, and thanks GW

6.52pm BST

Quick peek at Wall Street - the Dow Jones is still down, but only off 82 points at 15176. That's a drop of around 0.5%.

Looks like traders are sitting on their hands as the Shutdown Showdown plays out, rather than waving them in the air in a panicky fashion.

6.47pm BST

Hot off the Reuters terminal; more details of Silvio Berlusconi's showdown meeting with his party tonight.

A senior lawmaker from Silvio Berlusconi's People of Freedom (PDL) party said on Monday he was not satisfied after a party meeting at which Berlusconi sought to quell internal dissent with his decision to pull PDL's ministers from the government.

Up to 20 PDL Senators may be willing to defy Berlusconi and support Prime Minister Enrico Letta in a confidence vote on Wednesday, a PDL source told Reuters earlier on Monday.

"The situation has not been clarified," the PDL's former lower house leader Fabrizio Cicchitto told reporters after the meeting.

Cicchitto, one of the first PDL officials to express dissent with Berlusconi's decision on Saturday, said Berlusconi had left no room for debate after he had addressed the meeting and it was necessary to open a proper discussion in the party. 

6.38pm BST

A photo of a grim-faced Silvio Berlusconi arriving at the Italian parliament to meet with his party (and urge them to stick together) just landed:

6.36pm BST

Afternoon summary

Time for a summary of the main events of the day:

• America's government is on the brink of shutting down, but a last-gasp deal can't be ruled out. Politicians in Washington are making a final attempt to agree a new short-term budget deal before midnight tonight. The deadlock comes a Republicans try to force President Obama to accept delays and cuts to his landmark Affordable Healthcare act. Details here

My US colleagues will be covering the action over the next 12 hours here: US government shutdown looms as Congress fights over spending bill – live

• Italy remains locked in a political crisis tonight. Prime minister Enrico Letta is due to address the Italian parliament on Wednesday, and seek a confidence vote to discover whether he still has support to govern.

Analysts believe he could win the vote, but still be left struggling for authority.

• Tonight, Silvio Berlusconi has urged his party to stick together, amid reports that a group of senators are defying their leader -- concerned that he is trying to bring Letta down.

• European stock markets fell sharply this morning on fears over Italy's political crisis. The US shutdown also dominated the day, meaning the main indices all closed in the red. Here's the closing prices.

• Italy's borrowing costs spiked in early trading, but recovered somewhat this afternoon. It's 10-year bonds just closed, with yields up 15 basis points at 4.57%. 

• The US dollar was hit by events in Washington, pushing the pound over $1.62 for the first time since January.

• In Greece, the deputy prime minister has ruled out an early general election. Evangelos Venizelos made the pledge after a dramatic weekend in which many top officials in the neo Nazi Golden Dawn party were detained.

• While in the UK, chancellor George Osborne pledge to deliver a budget surplus in the next parliament. Full story here.

Updated at 7.11pm BST

6.02pm BST

Berlusconi calls on party to stay united

Developments in Italy tonight, where Silvio Berlusconi has met with his PDL party -- and appears to be softening his hard-line approach.

 Italian centre-right leader Silvio Berlusconi told his People of Freedom lawmakers that they must stick together after some party officials expressed dissent at his decision to withdraw the group's ministers from Prime Minister Enrico Letta's government.

"We must remain united," Berlusconi said, according to a parliamentarian present at the meeting who spoke on condition of anonymity.

He added he was willing to conditionally support the 2014 budget to be presented next month and other tax measures, but Italy should then hold a new election.

30-Sep-2013 17:49SENIOR PDL LAWMAKER SAYS AFTER PDL PARLIAMENTARIANS MEET BERLUSCONI THAT SITUATION IS STILL UNCLEAR, FURTHER MEETING NEEDED

30-Sep-2013 16:57 - BERLUSCONI TOLD PDL LAWMAKERS HE TOOK DECISION TO PULL MINISTERS FROM GOVERNMENT ALONE, THERE WAS NO SENSE IN REMAINING IN GOVERNMENT-SOURCE AT MEETING 

Certainly looks like Berlusconi might be backing away from bringing Enrico Letta's government crashing down.

5.30pm BST

Another angle on the US shutdown: (reminder: our American liveblog is here)

5.25pm BST

Unilever warns of emerging market slowdown

Consumer giant Unilever slipped out a trading update after trading on the London stock market closed, in which it admits that growth in emerging markets has stuttered by more than expected.

In a brief statement, it explained that will tell investors this week that it is "on track to meet its 2013 priorities", despite "slower market growth" in many emerging countries.

Here's the key message: 

Unilever will say that it has seen weakening in the market growth of many emerging countries in quarter three and now expects underlying sales growth of 3 to 3.5% in the quarter. The emerging market slow-down has accelerated as a result of significant currency weakening. Developed markets remain flat to down.

 That compares with underlying sales growth of 5% in the previous three months. A slowdown indeed.

5.12pm BST

European market close

Europe's stock markets are closed, with losses across the board.

However, the shares did recover some ground from this morning's early tumble, reflecting speculation that Silvio Berlusconi may have overplayed his hand by hauling his ministers out of the Italian government.

Closing prices:

• Italian FTSE MIB: down 211 points at 17,434, -1.2%

• FTSE 100: down 50 points at 6462, = 0.5%

• German DAX: down 67 points at 8, 594, -0.77%

• French CAC: down 43 points at 4,143, -1%

• Spanish IBEX: down 42 points at 9,186, -0.46%

Reaction to follow

4.37pm BST

Government shutdowns can have unintended consequences:

The Starr report into the affair appears to stand this up.

4.23pm BST

Heads-up, the pound just hit $1.62 $1.6197 against the US dollar, its highest level since the start of the year.

Updated at 4.26pm BST

4.22pm BST

While 10-year US bonds prices are slightly weaker today, the price of five-year Treasury bills has actually risen a small amount today.

4.14pm BST

Back in the eurozone, then. And buried in the market action is a small rally in Greek bonds today.

Bond traders seem to be welcoming the long-hoped-for clampdown on Golden Dawn, and the pledge from the Greek deputy prime minister that a new general election won't be triggered.

This has pushed Greek bond prices up, lowering the yield on its 10-year debt by 15 basis points to 9.41%, down from 9.56%. on Friday night.

4.05pm BST

Our new Shutdown Showdown liveblog is launched

My colleagues in America have launched a new liveblog, covering every twist and turn as America ploughs towards a government shutdown at midnight tonight (or 5am BST tomorrow)

It explains how politicians in Washington could pull a deal out of the fire:

The Senate meets at 2pm to strip the Obamacare delay out of the spending bill and pass it "clean." That is expected to happen fairly quickly, according to congressional staffers Dan's been speaking with. Then the bill goes back to the House, which will be waiting to put health care measures back in, including the so-called Vitter amendment which would require members of Congress personally to receive Obamacare.

The legislation thus laden should then likely have time to bounce back to the Senate, where it would be indignantly ignored. 

Tom McCarthy is at the controls:

US government shutdown looms as Congress fights over spending bill – live

Updated at 4.06pm BST

3.44pm BST

Here's Reuters early stock market report from the floor of Wall Street:

U.S. stocks fell sharply on Monday as a last-minute deal to resolve a budget impasse in Washington appeared less likely, increasing the chances of a partial government shutdown.

Losses were broad, with all ten S&P 500 sectors lower on the day, led by energy and financials shares.

About 80% of companies traded on both the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq fell.

The House of Representatives early on Sunday voted for an emergency spending bill that includes a one-year delay of President Barack Obama's signature healthcare overhaul despite threats of a veto from the White House.

A shutdown would have wide-ranging implications for a most types of assets. If a deal is reached quickly, markets might recover, but a prolonged shutdown could do significant harm to the economy and consumer confidence. While a deal could still be reached before the government's fiscal year ends at midnight on Monday, such a possibility was considered unlikely.

Up to 1 million government employees could be furloughed by the absence of a deal, and if the shutdown takes place, the Labor Department will postpone issuing its closely watched monthly employment report scheduled for Friday.

"The government is such an important part of the entire economy, between the people it employs and the impact it has on consumer confidence," said Nicholas Colas, chief market strategist at the ConvergEx Group in New York.

"The size of the selloff is logical given the stakes."

3.37pm BST

There's absolutely no chance that the US will default on its debts next month, argues Rick Rieder of BlackRock, the group's co-head of fixed investment in the Americas.

He's certain that politicians will agree a deal to raise the debt ceiling before October 17, when funds run out, even if the US Federal government shuts down at midnight tonight.

Speaking on Bloomberg TV's snappily-named "Shutdown Showdown", Rieder predicted a repeat of the events of 2011, when a deal was reached at the last minute.

Reider added:

I definitely have a sense that they won' t push it over the edge.

3.30pm BST

Worth noting that there's no significant move in the price of US Treasuries today (yet anyway).

Despite the imminent danger that hundreds of thousands of Federal government workers are about to take an unscheduled, unpaid break, US government bonds are changing hands for virtually the same price as last Friday.

The 10-year Treasury Bill has dropped very slightly in value, pushing up its bond yield by just 0.02 percentage points to 2.63%, up from 2.61%.

3.25pm BST

Italian government bonds are recovering on the back of the rumours that 20 Italian senators are threatening to break away from Silvio Berlusconi's party, and potentially support prime minister Enrico Letta.

Italy's debt is still down on the day, pushing up its 10-year bond yields by 15 basis points at 4.58%. But that's rather lower than the peak this morning -- showing less panic over the situation in Rome.

3.10pm BST

Like the Dow Jones index on Wall Street, European stock markets also remain in the red. They are being pulled lower by a mixture of US shutdown fears and Italian political chaos.

Those reports of a revolt against Silvio Berlusconi by his own senators (see 2.29pm) have eased worries, a little bit:

• Italian FTSE MIB: down 296 points at 17350, -1.67% 

• FTSE 100: down 51 points at 6461, -0.8%

• German DAX: down 96 points at 8565, -1.1%

• French CAC: down 57 points at 4129, -1.3%

• Spanish IBEX: down 88 points at 9140, -0.95%

3.09pm BST

A last-minute compromise in America to avoid a government shutdown isn't impossible, but it's not looking likely, as CBNC explains:

One thing we know for sure about today: The Senate will reconvene this afternoon and kill the bill passed by the House over the weekend to fund the government in return for a one-year delay in the president's health care bill along with other provisions Democrats will never accept.

Majority Leader Harry Reid, D-Nev., and the Senate Democratic majority will then send a clean government funding bill back to the House where Speaker John Boehner, R-Ohio, will have just a few hours to figure out how to respond.

If no deal is reached, the federal government will begin closing down non-essential operations and send hundreds of thousands of workers home.

 And the big question swirling around Washington, Wall Street, and beyond is clear -- how will a shutdown hurt attempts to raise the US debt ceiling before October 17, when the US could default.

3.01pm BST

Ishaq Siddiqi, market strategist at ETX Capital, explains that traders are furiously trying to calculate the impact of a US government shutdown. It's clearly not great news for the economy, thus the drop on the Dow this morning.

One side-effect of a shutdown is that the monthly US jobs report might not be released on Friday. Without a Non-Farm Payroll reading, it will be harder for the Federal Reserve to judge whether to slow its monetary stimulus programme.

He writes:

At a time when economic growth is fragile at best, the market is now working out the implications of what the economic impact could be on Q4 growth.

Not always easy to measure something like this as talks between lawmakers continues but what is fast accepted in the market is that tapering by the Fed may be held off for this year. Fed head Bernanke will not fire the tapering trigger until the fiscal situation is under control which could take longer than he and the markets had anticipated.

Updated at 3.05pm BST

2.58pm BST

Every stock on the Dow Jones is in the red this morning. The biggest fallers are Goldman Sachs (down 1.9%), Boeing (-1.6%) and Nike (down 1.5%).

The Dow itself has settled down around 160 points lower at 15100, -1%.

2.45pm BST

Looks like a nice day in Washington for a last-ditch attempt to avoid non-essential government services being shut down:

2.37pm BST

That's a bigger drop on the Dow Jones than expected (although the Dow takes around 15 minutes to fully open).

Updated at 2.37pm BST

2.36pm BST

Wall Street opens down

Wall Street is open, and shares are sliding.

The Dow Jones industrial average has slid 170 points in the early moments of trading, as traders dash to offload shares in the face of a US government shutdown. That's a drop of 1.1%, to 15087.

Similar tale on the tech stock-heavy Nasdaq, down over 1%. 

Details to follow

Updated at 2.36pm BST

2.29pm BST

Reuters: Berlusconi faces revolt from his own senators

Back to Italy, where there are reports of a revolt against Silvio Berlusconi from some of his own senators over his decision to effectively declare war on prime minister Enrico Letta over the weekend.

Reuters is reporting that up to 20 of Berlusconi's centre-right group are threatening to form a breakaway faction in the Senate.

Here's the story: 

As many as 20 senators from the centre-right party of Silvio Berlusconi are ready to form a breakaway group unless the former premier backs down on his hard line to bring down Italy's government and head to elections, a top member of the party told Reuters on Monday.

The threat, which lawmakers from the People of Freedom Party (PDL) are going to level at Berlusconi during a meeting on Monday, may give Prime Minister Enrico Letta a chance to save his government after five PDL ministers resigned on Saturday.

Letta is going before parliament for a confidence vote on Wednesday and needs to secure a majority in the Senate - where the PDL is currently the second-largest party -- in order to continue in government.

2.20pm BST

Republican speaker John Boehner is one of the key players in today's last-ditch struggle to avoid the US government shutting town,

 National Review's Washington editor Robert Costa reports that he grabbed a few words with Boehner at Pete's Diner.

Boehner has been criticised for failing to keep the Republican wing of Congress under control -- guests on Bloomberg TV early this morning chastised Boehner for not handling the Tea Party element better.

2.12pm BST

Tensions rising in Italy too -- the head of the banking association says he's worried about government stability, and fears "serious damage" to Italy.

And the head of the country's UIL union has warned that Italy could find itself run by the Troika unless it has a stable administration.

Thirdly, ratings agency Fitch has warned that it could downgrade Italy if the country's government does fall, as its "short and medium-term fiscal policy targets" would be at risk.

That may not capture the full importance of Wednesday's government confidence vote

2.04pm BST

Are Western countries lurching into an autumn of disorder? 

Leading economist Nouriel Roubini is certainly worried, citing five separate factors:

• the risk of the US government shutting down. There's less than a day to go to hammer out a deal, and economists fear that a shutdown could scupper the recovery

• Italy's fragile government which faces a confidence vote on Wednesday, after Silvio Berlusconi order his ministers to quit the cabinet

• the crackdown on neoNazis in Greece, which could provoke political instability

• the Portuguese goverment's drubbing in local elections yesterday, and

• the slow progress on forming a new German government (a deal could be weeks away)

1.35pm BST

There's a certain degree of cynicism over the antics in Washington:

1.33pm BST

There's still hope, though, that a US government shutdown can be averted in time.

For that to happen, the Republican-controlled Congress would have to vote through a new funding framework for October onwards that is acceptable to the Democrat-controlled Senate. Before midnight.

Republican senator John Thune of South Dakota reckons there's still time for compromise. He told Bloomberg that he's "still hopeful" that shutdown can be avoided, if "the Congress could send something back that can be approved by the Senate".

As explained earlier, Congress did pass a budget over the weekend, but it included cuts and delays to the President Obama's Affordable Healthcare Act that aren't acceptable to the Democrats. 

1.13pm BST

US heads towards the shutdown

It's almost quarter past eight in the morning on the East Coast of the US, which means less than 16 hours until the Federal government will shut down unless a budget for 2013-2014 is approved.

Bloomberg's Washington reporter Peter Cook reports that security officers on Capitol Hill say they expect that the shutdown will take place, adding:

Everyone is betting on a shutdown at midnight.

And political analyst Matt Dowd explains that "a huge section of the Republican party" wants to shut the government down, which makes a last-ditch deal less likely.

Philosophically they think shutting down the government is a good thing.

Sounds like they might get their wish....

Updated at 1.14pm BST

1.00pm BST

I've pulled together a short explainer of how the American government has been dragged to the brink of shutdown, for readers outside the US:

US shutdown: an explainer for non-Americans

12.44pm BST

Greek deputy PM rules out early elections

Over in Greece deputy prime minister Evangelos Venizelos has just given a press conference in which he ruled out the country going to early elections, following the crackdown on the far-right Golden Dawn party.

Our correspondent in Athens, Helena Smith reports.

Evangelos Venizelos said the arrests of “a large number ”of Golden Dawn's MPs would not be the spur for fresh elections. 

Athens’ two-party coalition “will exhaust its four year term with the goal of creating a programme that will given prospect and hope to the Greek people,” he told reporters. “The country, right now, has immediate goals,” he said insisting that it was imperative the government focus on ongoing negotiations with Greece’s “troika” of foreign lenders at the EU, ECB and IMF.

“The last thing this place needs is political upheaval. Can you see what is happening in Italy?” he asked adding that financial markets were already reacting badly to developments there “and Italy’s the eighth-largest economy in the world.”

But the politician, who is also foreign minister, acknowledged that the neo-nazi party had become “as big a topic as the economic crisis” afflicting Greece in his discussions with foreign leaders in New York where he attended the UN’s general assembly last week.

Mission heads representing the troika are expected to return to Athens immediately after the next Euro group meeting of euro zone finance ministers on October 14 to close discussions on a third rescue programme for the debt-stricken country.

Meanwhile, in the wake of the arrest of Golden Dawn MPs and others, inquires are continuing apace with authorities this morning reportedly unearthing “a heap” of Nazi paraphernalia in the home of Christos Pappas, the party’s parliamentary spokesman accused of being the second-in-command of the criminal gang the extremists also allegedly ran.

12.31pm BST

Oh, and chancellor Osborne also pledged to freeze fuel duty until 2015 -- so long as the coalition can find the money (ie, if the Liberal Democrats agree).

12.26pm BST

A couple of interesting lines from George Osborne's Tory conference speech (live blog here).

The Italian political crisis, and the looming threat of the US government shutdown, is proof that "the debt crisis isn't over".

Osborne cited an old favourite, the Greek slump. "Ask people in Greece what happens when economies fail."

And he also pledged that a future Conservative government would plan to run a budget surplus in future years, during the 'good times'. Still some work to do, though, with Britain running a deficit of more than one hundred billion pounds this year.

Updated at 12.27pm BST

12.16pm BST

Italian bond yields remain higher

Back in the financial markets, Italian government debt is still down today, but has recovered partly from its early selloff.

The yield (effectively the interest rate) on 10-year Italian bonds is currently 4.65%, from 4.42% on Friday, reflecting a drop in the value of the bonds this morning.

In comparison, Spanish 10-year yields are 4.38% -- Rome has replaced Madrid as the bigger risk to eurozone stability.

Still well below the 7% level where a country has lost the power to fund itself. Italian debt is still protected by the European Central Bank's pledge to buy unlimited quantities of its bonds if needed.

However.... that ECB promise required a country to sign up for 'conditionality' in return -- such as economic reforms and fiscal targets. Could Rome really promise that, given the political instability? And could the ECB believe it?

Updated at 12.17pm BST

11.49am BST

Up in Manchester, chancellor George Osborne is about to give a speech on the UK economy at the Conservative Party conference. There's live coverage in Andrew Sparrow's live blog:

11.36am BST

Bloomberg's Europe editor, David Tweed, has been canvassing Italian politicians. Some are confidently predicting that Enrico Letta will win Wednesday's confidence vote (where the real challenge is in the Senate, where Letta's PD party doesn't have a guaranteed majority).

Here's the details, with a video embedded in the third tweet:

11.32am BST

Another of our go-to guys on Italian politics, Alberto Nardelli, agrees that another Italian general election couldn't be held until the end of November.

He also flags up some key points, including that the radical Five Star Movement is enjoying a revival in the polls.

Here's a flavour:

Additional factors to keep an eye on:

- the M5S after a post-election drop, is once again above 20% in polls.

- within Berlusconi’s PDL there is a clearly divided on direction to take - several senior figures have voiced concerns over the decision to pull the plug on the government. The party is internally arguing and fighting over its future - splits are possible.

11.19am BST

Analysis of the Italian political situation

There's some good political analysis around this morning about Italy.

The Open Europe thinktank first. It explains that there are two scenarios now that Silvio Berlusconi has withdrawn his ministers from Enrico Letta's government. Either Letta wins Wednesday's confidence vote, or he loses it. 

Both are plausible. And curiously, while a defeat wouldn't trigger an immediate general election, a victory wouldn't cement Letta's authority.

Scenario 1 - Letta survives the confidence vote in the Senate

Tough, but definitely not unrealistic. Letta needs around 20 Senators from either Berlusconi's party or Beppe Grillo's Five-Star Movement to break ranks and support him. Over the past few days, politicians from both parties have hinted at the possibility of defections. Crucially, after tendering their resignations, four of Berlusconi's ministers have expressed reservations over their leader's decision to open a new political crisis at this stage. All this suggests Letta does have a chance of winning the vote in the Italian Senate, and staying in power with a different, albeit thinner, parliamentary majority (and after a rather substantial cabinet reshuffle).

However, this would only be a temporary fix. With his new majority, Letta could try and address a couple of urgent issues (a reform of Italy's tortuous electoral law and the budget for 2014 are the most obvious) - and perhaps plan for early elections at some point next year.

Scenario 2 - Letta loses the confidence vote

If Letta loses the confidence vote, he will have to resign. As we explained several times, the ball would then be in Italian President Giorgio Napolitano's court. Napolitano would have to hold talks with all the political parties and then make a decision: task Letta himself or someone else with forming a new government, or dissolve parliament and call new elections.

New elections in Italy can take place no less than 45 days after parliament is dissolved. The risks of a quick return to the polls are obvious. Voting again with the same electoral law may well lead to another inconclusive outcome - meaning that Italy could be facing a few months of political paralysis at a time when the country can least afford it. As if things were not complicated enough, the electoral law is currently being examined by the Italian Constitutional Court, with a ruling expected in early December - and is at risk of being declared at least in part unconstitutional.

This is where we are at. Clearly, none of the two scenarios would provide the medium-term political stability Italy needs to get its act together - which in itself is not great news for both the country and the eurozone as a whole. Everything will depend on how Wednesday's vote of confidence goes. 

11.04am BST

The consumer price index slid to just 1.1% in August, despite the European Central Bank keeping interest rates at record lows of just 0.5%. That looks like a clear signal that the ECB could ease monetary policy further without risking price stability.

The overall inflation rate is being driven down by falling prices in some of the countries gripped by austerity, notable Greece which has been experiencing deflation in recent months.

The ECB's governing council will meet this week to discuss policy -- with a decision and press conference due on Wednesday (a day earlier than usual). The same day as the Italian parliament will hold a vote of confidence in Enrico Letta's government....

9.45am BST

The revival in Britain's housing market continues, with mortgage approvals hitting their highest level since February 2008.

A total of 62,226 mortgages were signed in August, up from 60,900 in July, the Bank of England reported.

That's even before the UK government brought forward the second stage of its Help to Buy scheme - in which taxpayers will guarantee a slice of a mortgage. 

If mortgage approvals are so healthy, why the need to rush forwards Help to Buy?....

As things stand, the Congress (controlled by Republicans) is unlikely to pass a budget for 2014 that will not include cuts to President Obama's health reforms. It's equally implausible that such a budget could get through the Senate (controlled by Democrats), or be approved by the White House. 

If that happens, non-essential government staff would be forced to take unpaid holiday - for the first time in 17 years.

A shutdown could have serious consequences for the US economy, as Jane Foley of Rabobank explains:

The costs of a government shutdown clearly depend on its duration. Moody’s estimate that a 3 to 4 week closure of government would knock 1.4% of GDP growth in Q3 and that a 2 week closure would slice away 0.3%.

The row is particularly serious as the US government is also close to hitting its debt ceiling - under American law it's only allowed to owe $16.7 trillion (say it fast and it doesn't sound as much).

Washington needs to reach a deal on the debt ceiling soon, probably before 17 October when US borrowing is expected to hit the legal limit. Breach that, and America could default.

It's just 4.35am in New York but, as Business Insider reports, Wall Street is expected to join in the selloff when trading begins later today.

9.15am BST

We might have expected a bigger market reaction to the prospect of the Italian government imploding.

I mean, a 2% drop on the Milan stock market is serious, but not actually deadly. Likewise, Italian borrowing costs have jumped, but are still below the 5% mark -- let alone the 7% 'danger zone'.

The reason, I think, it's not clear who will be the big loser by the end of this week – prime minister Enrico Letta, or Silvio Belusconi.

As my colleague Lizzy Davies explained last night, Silvio Berlusconi faces growing dissent from his own party members over his decision to order his ministers to withdraw from Enrico Letta's administration.

Lizzy writes that four of these ministers have now criticised the move: 

The most stinging blow came from Angelino Alfano, Berlusconi's right-hand man, who has been acting as deputy PM and interior minister in the Letta coalition. He said that if Forza Italia were to be dominated by extreme positions, he would have to be "a Berlusconi-ite in a different way".

The unprecedented dissent from within his own party appeared to prompt the three-times prime minister to tone down his high-stakes strategy, which earlier in the day saw him triumphantly declare that he was "ready to take up the battle again".

Silvio Berlusconi faces rebellion from allies after chaotic weekend

8.48am BST

In other election news, Portugal's government was pummeled in local elections yesterday, as anger over the country's austerity programme hit its support. The Social Democrats won just 17% of the vote, while the opposition Socialists scooped 36%.

The hammering comes just two weeks before the government delivers its proposed 2014 budget, which will include another round of spending cuts.

8.45am BST

Both the Social Democrats and the Conservatives attracted a smaller share of the vote than last time, but appear to have enough votes to keep governing.

The Freedom Party of Austria, which ran on an anti-immigration and anti-Islam ticket, won 21.4% of the vote.

8.31am BST

Italy risks being the source of latest fireworks with Prime Minister Letta confirming he is seeking a vote of confidence after Berlusconi (who may be ejected from Senate due to tax-fraud) ordered (yes, he’s still running the show) the withdrawal of 5 cabinet members from his party’s wing within the young coalition and emphasised its fragility.

Golden Dawn raids leave Greek neo-Nazis reeling

The other dramatic development over the weekend was the Greek government cracking down on the neo-Nazi Golden Dawn party.

Sixteen party activists, including its leader Nikos Michaloliakos, were detained in a series of early-morning raids on Saturday. Yesterday, the party's spokesman surrendered, after 24 hours on the run.

As Helena Smith reported from Athens:

A Greek MP said to be the second in command of the far-right Golden Dawn party has surrendered after authorities arrested the organisation's leader and other key members on charges of running a criminal gang.

Christos Pappas, the party's parliamentary spokesman and unrepentant holder of many of its most hardline views, handed himself over to police more than 24 hours after an unprecedented crackdown on the neo-fascist group began.

Appearing at Athens's central police headquarters in a taxi, the politician insisted the vehemently anti-immigrant party would "survive … the political persecution" it was being subjected to.

Golden Dawn MP Christos Pappas surrenders to Greek police

The arrests have been hailed as a long-awaited move against the party. But it also raises the prospect of political instability in Greece, should Golden Dawn's MPs resign and trigger a series of by-elections. The Greek coalition government only has a slender majority.

7.07am BST

US heading for shutdown, Italian government faces meltdown

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and the business world.

Political instability is building on both sides of the Atlantic, sending shivers through the financial world as investors contemplate an autumn of drama and turbulence.

Asian stock markets have already posted heavy losses, with the Japanese Nikkei sliding 1.8%. European markets are likely to drop by at least 1% when trading begins.

As Chris Weston, IG's man in Melbourne, put it:

The news flow has turned decisively negative in the last few days. 

In America, the government is on the verge of shutting down, with Democrats and Republicans unable to agree a new spending bill.

If a deal can't be struck by midnight tonight then Washington should shutdown, leaving federal workers unpaid and leaving government in limbo. Republicans continue to insist on making swingeing cuts to Obamacare, the president's healthcare policies, in return for approving the budget. Barack Obama refuses to accept such a plan.

While in Italy, prime minister Enrico Letta is battling to hold his government together. On Saturday, disgraced former-PM Silvio Berlusconi ordered ministers from his party to withdraw from Letta's shaky coalition. They did so, triggering a new political crisis in Rome.

Letta has now called a confidence vote on Wednesday, that will show whether he can continue to govern. Should he fall, Italy could be dragged back into the eurozone crisis.

It's going to be a dramatic week....

webTitle: George Osborne's surplus will need yet more cuts

fields.bodyText: It's not over. The job is only half done. There's hard graft ahead. Dealing with debt addiction will take time. That was the message from George Osborne as he offered voters what he called "a serious plan for a grown-up country". The chancellor's speech to the Conservative party conference was both a statement of the obvious and a piece of political positioning. It has taken far, far longer than the Treasury expected for growth to return to the economy, but, fortunately for Osborne, voters still blame the last Labour government rather than the current administration for the delay. When the chancellor said "the battle to turn Britain around" was not over, the subtext was that voters should think twice before putting Ed Miliband and Ed Balls in charge. In place of Labour's failure to "mend the roof while the sun was shining," the next Conservative government would start to pay down the national debt by running a budget surplus during the course of the next parliament. This was making a virtue of necessity. The 2010 forecasts made when Osborne took over at the Treasury from Alistair Darling saw the economy growing at almost 3% in both 2012 and 2013, with deep cuts in the budget deficit as a result. The chancellor boasted on Monday that public borrowing had been cut by a third since the coalition came to power; what he did not say was that it is still expected to be £120bn this year – double what was envisaged in 2010. Osborne has already abandoned his original aim of sorting out the public finances in one parliament, with two extra years of deficit reduction pencilled in during the first two years after the 2015 election. on Monday, the chancellor went further, announcing that a Conservative government would run a budget surplus in the next parliament. This is some commitment. Capital spending on the UK's infrastructure will be £25bn a year on existing plans and will rise in line with economic growth during the next parliament. The Treasury will need to squeeze current spending if it is to achieve an overall surplus. Is this possible? The ringfencing of spending on the NHS, schools and overseas development means that there have already been deep cuts in the budgets of other Whitehall departments. Researchers at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, Britain's leading thinktank on tax and spending matters, were already sceptical about whether spending on the police, the courts and other non-ringfenced activities could be cut much further even before Osborne's latest pledge. That's not to say it is impossible for a surplus to be run in the next parliament. It will, however, require two things: reductions in welfare spending and a prolonged period of steady growth. The chancellor admitted that without the latter, his plan would be a dead duck. Growth prospects look good in the short term. The economy grew by 0.7% in the second quarter of 2013 and the City is expecting a similar rate of expansion in the third quarter. Bringing forward phase two of Help to Buy, the government scheme to subsidise house buying, from early 2014 to next week will help to keep the property market humming. Osborne staunchly defended Help to Buy, and it is backed by the CBI, which says it was vital in turning the economy around earlier this year. But by pushing up house prices it will result in higher mortgages and more private borrowing. The chancellor said victory would not be achieved until he had weaned Britain off its debt addiction. Don't hold your breath. As with the pledge to run a budget surplus, it may be some time in coming.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer Asia boss Pascal Martin departs

fields.standfirst: Martin's departure comes as M&S reviews its operations in fast-growing Chinese market
fields.body:
The revolving door has turned again at Marks & Spencer with the head of the retailer's Asian operations exiting the business after less than two years.

Pascal Martin, who joined from Burberry in January 2012 departs in the wake of Janie Schaffer, who left just three months after she joined from US brand Victoria's Secret to become M&S's head of lingerie, while the long-term head of clothing and homewares, Kate Bostock, left in 2012. The head of marketing, Steve Sharp, will step down in February.

The latest change comes as M&S reviews its operations in the fast-growing Chinese market. The company, which owns 16 stores in mainland China and 15 in Hong Kong, said earlier this year that it was looking at partnerships or franchise agreements to take the business forward.

While sales are growing strongly in China, where M&S opened its first store in 2008, analysts believe M&S is not trading profitably there, with tough competition and rising costs in Hong Kong.

"I don't think M&S has ever made any money in Shanghai," said Credit Suisse analyst Simon Irwin. "It's not about local management; M&S made the wrong strategic decisions."

A change in tack in China would follow a similar move by Tesco, which is expected to confirm details of a joint venture with state-owned company China Resources Enterprise later this week. The supermarket is joining its 131 stores with CRE's 2,986 Vanguard sites in return for a 20% stake in the bigger company after struggling to achieve profitable growth in China.

M&S is replacing Martin with Bruce Findlay, previously regional director of Europe for US brand Calvin Klein. He will take charge of more than 120 stores in nine territories including India, China, and Hong Kong, as well as franchise stores in Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, South Korea and Thailand.

M&S operating profits for Asia fell 15.4% last year.

webTitle: McLaren drives down losses and expects to break even this year

fields.standfirst: Supercar manufacturer says operating losses fell to £10.9m last year from £59.1m in 2011 as sales almost quadruple
fields.body:
McLaren Automotive, the luxury sports car business of the Formula 1 group, sharply reduced its losses in 2012 and has set its sights on Asia to boost future growth.

Operating losses at the three-year-old business fell to £10.9m last year from £59.1m in 2011 and it expects to break even this year.

The company said demand for its latest offering, the P1 hybrid supercar, had been exceptionally strong, with potential customers "invited to apply" to buy one.

McLaren Automotive will build just 375 P1s, which cost £866,000 and can achieve 0-62mph in less than three seconds. The majority of the cars have already been pre-sold, with allocations in the US and Asia sold out.

Last year sales almost quadrupled to 1,587 cars from 400 in 2011, as the company benefited from the first full year of production of the McLaren 12C and the launch year of the 12C Spider.

Turnover rose to £266.6m last year from £68.9m.

Mike Flewitt, chief executive of McLaren Automotive, said it was already producing some of the world's most "technologically advanced high performance sports cars".

"We will continue to deliver groundbreaking cars to customers around the world, continue to push the boundaries of automotive technology and continue to establish ourselves as a significant force in the high-performance automotive market."

Around 80% of the cars made at the group's Woking factory are exported, and McLaren Automotive has about 50 dealerships across the world, including most recently China.

webTitle: US, Italian and Greek political woes hit FTSE 100, but builders buoyed by Help to Buy

fields.standfirst: Leading shares end month on a negative note as US government faces shutdown and Italy sees confidence vote
fields.body:
Markets ended the month on a downbeat note as political chaos in the US and Europe sent shares sharply lower.

As the deadline approached for a US government shutdown, with politicians looking unlikely to reach an agreement on the country's budget, investors headed for safety. Elsewhere the Italian government faced the prospect of a confidence vote on Wednesday after Silvio Berlusconi told his party to resign from the coalition, while in Greece the arrest of Golden Dawn members renewed political uncertainty in the struggling country.

On top of that an HSBC manufacturing survey for China came in at 50.2, up from 50.1 but lower than the initial reading of 51.2.

webTitle: Aldi aims to open 50 new UK stores this year

fields.standfirst: German supermarket says 500th shop will open in Suffolk this month after sales soared 40% in 2012
fields.body:
The German supermarket Aldi is aiming to open 50 new stores in the UK this year after sales soared 40% to £3.9bn in 2012. The retailer said it would open its 500th store, in Suffolk, later this month after opening 34 new stores last year and adding 1 million more shoppers.

Aldi, which sells a limited range of own-label groceries at low prices, has been grabbing market share from mainstream supermarkets such as Tesco, Asda and Morrisons as shoppers seek out a bargain during the economic downturn.

The chain still has a relatively tiny share of the market at 3.7%, according to the latest figures from the market analysts Kantar Worldpanel, but is seeing growth of 32.7% while bigger rivals struggle. Almost one in three households now visit Aldi at least once a month according to another research agency, Nielsen.

The company said it had experienced strong sales of fresh fruit, vegetables and meat, despite its links to the horsemeat scandal. Earlier this year, it was found that two Aldi beef products contained up to 100% horsemeat.

Aldi has been attempting to attract more middle-class customers by moving into more affluent locations such as Winchester, Hampshire, and Knutsford, Cheshire, and broadening the range of products it sells from 800 to 1,350. It is also trying out more upmarket items such as lobster tails and a three-bird roast for Christmas.

The joint group managing director Roman Heini said: "We believe growth is down to one thing – customers demanding true value."

webTitle: Ladbrokes continues to slide after profit warning

fields.standfirst: Gaming group hit by further downgrades as company struggles with its online business
fields.body:
Ladbrokes is continuing its decline after Thursday's profit warning due to problems at its online operations.

The company is struggling to set up a new digital business with partner Playtech at the same time as running down its existing platform. This is proving harder than expected, not least because morale at the existing business has been hit by the upheaval.

The disappointing update has put pressure on chief executive Richard Glynn and could leave the company vulnerable to a predator. Its shares fell 9% last week after the warning and have now fallen another 2.1p - more than 1% - to 169.6p as UBS cut its price target from 195p to 165p and Numis moved from add to hold. Numis analyst Ivor Jones said:

In the first half of 2010, Ladbrokes reported £29m of Digital earnings before interest and tax. In 2H13, we forecast near nil. It still has a material customer base, a powerful brand and access to the cashflow of the shops. In the second half of 2014, it should have in place the peculiar arrangement of having its own Digital employees in Israel and paying Playtech according to their success. The building blocks are, therefore, in place for a revival, but execution is too uncertain.
Strategically management should perhaps have had the Israel/Playtech business in a better state of readiness before winding down the London/Microgaming-based operations. Certainly, market guidance should have been consistent with the uncertainty of the task attempted, in our view. Digital's strategic direction still seems attractive even if the journey is more tortuous than expected. The destination may be appealing, but the failures of execution and communication so far make us more sceptical about the ability of management to get us there. And the new model will only be in place in the second half of 2014, which means that the first substantive progress report may be a year away.

webTitle: Norway's sovereign wealth fund 'is example for oil-rich nations'

fields.standfirst: Former PM Jens Stoltenberg says indebted European nations should look to Norway's £460bn fund to avert 'curse of oil'
fields.body:
Norway has much to teach spendthrift nations such as the UK, its outgoing prime minister has said.

Jens Stoltenberg said indebted European nations should look to Norway, which has become one of the wealthiest countries in the world mainly by refusing to spend its huge oil revenues and placing them instead in a sovereign wealth fund.

"That way the fund lasts for ever," he said in a speech at Harvard University. "The problem in Europe with the deficits and the debt crisis is that many European countries have spent money they don't have. The problem in Norway is that we don't spend money we do have. That requires a kind of political courage."

Norway's sovereign wealth fund is the biggest in the world at £460bn. The fund generates money from its ownership of petroleum fields, taxes on oil and gas, and dividends from a 67% stake in Statoil, the country's largest energy company. Norway is the world's second-largest gas exporter and the seventh-largest oil exporter.

Stoltenberg, a Labour party member who served two consecutive four-year terms as prime minister, said his administration restricted itself to spending the investment gains made by the fund.

He said the fund was the main reason Norway sidestepped the "curse of oil" that has plagued many other resource-rich nations, particularly in the developing world.

"There are many, many other countries in the world that are in similar positions, that are facing the same kinds of challenges that we are facing: huge temporary income from natural resources," he said. "So, if there is a danger of an oil curse, Norway is really exposed to that danger. But we have managed to avoid it. The oil industry has been a blessing for Norway."

Maintaining the policy has not been pain-free for the nation. In 2009, the fund's value slumped in the wake of the Lehman Brothers crash. The loss of £56bn was equivalent to £11,000 per person. Since then, its investment strategy has widened its scope to include Asian assets, and property including a multimillion-pound purchase of shop leases on London's Regent Street.

Argument raged during the recent election over how much of the fund's revenues to invest. The far-right Progress party, which is expected to enter a coalition with the more mainstream Conservative party, wants to spend more of the fund on welfare to enable tax cuts. A broad consensus among politicians of all major parties that spending the oil funds would corrupt the nation and encourage young people to become dissolute means the proposal is unlikely to gain much traction.

Britain, too, had the luxury of significant oil and gas funds, but successive governments have faced criticism for frittering them away on maintaining inefficient industries rather than saving the money in a sovereign wealth fund. Britain became a net importer of oil in 2003 and has faced a worsening balance of payments deficit and decline in tax revenues as a result, without a wealth fund to soften the blow.

webTitle: Turn crown estate into sovereign wealth fund, Labour MPs to urge

fields.bodyText: Britain's £8.6bn crown estate should be turned into a sovereign wealth fund to rival government-backed investment funds that have sprung up across Europe, the Middle East and Asia in the last 20 years, a group of Labour MPs will say this week. The MPs will tell the Co-op party's annual conference on Friday that the crown estate, which comprises vast tracts of land and commercial property across the UK, should be freed up to invest in foreign property and much-needed infrastructure projects in Britain. Gareth Thomas, chair of the Co-op party's group of 33 Labour MPs, said such a sovereign wealth fund could boost growth and help pay the UK's debts. Thomas said: "A British sovereign wealth fund could promote co-operation with fast-growing overseas businesses, earning the UK vital income over the long term. "Modernising the rules governing the crown estate could, for example, allow it to invest in up-and-coming property markets in G20 states like China and India or in new technology businesses, helping Britain secure access to innovative ideas developed abroad." The estate manages the £8.6bn of land and property that the crown owns, but which the Queen does not control and cannot sell. The estate is accountable to parliament, and pays its surplus income to the Treasury to offset the cost of maintaining the royal family. The Treasury said there were no plans to develop a UK sovereign wealth fund to rival the £15bn French and £875m Italian government funds, though the local government minister, Eric Pickles, is consulting on whether to create a "superfund" from the UK's assorted state pension schemes, which have amassed almost £200bn in assets. There are 89 local government pension schemes, with around £150bn under management; several others, including the Royal Mail pension scheme and the fund for MPs' pensions, have built up assets from investments in shares and bonds. However, pension funds are excluded from the list of sovereign wealth funds, which are expected to generate wealth for the nation as a whole. Thomas said that, with a change in the law lifting restrictions that limit it to property and land in Britain, the crown estate could become a sovereign wealth fund and develop its investment strategy. Last year the estate generated a surplus of £253m from its investments after making an 11.9% annual return. The bedrock of the estate is the Prince Regent's London property holdings, built 200 years ago, which run from Regent's Park through Oxford Circus and Regent Street to St James's Park. Seabeds managed by the estate are leased to offshore windfarms, and land across the UK is home to many other renewable energy schemes, business parks and factories. The fund was boosted last year by the acquisition of the Coliseum shopping park, in Cheshire, and Silverlink shopping park, outside Newcastle. Lifting restrictions on the estate would, Thomas said, allow it "to begin to explore ventures into overseas property markets, for example in the Asian Pacific region, where eight of the world's largest 20 property markets are located, including China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and India, or taking a stake in companies set up to bring new technologies to market". Most of the largest funds rely on oil and other commodity revenues to boost their assets under management. Norway already has a £460bn sovereign wealth fund generated from taxes on its oil and gas industry. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and China have also amassed huge wealth in funds that have become active investors in foreign markets, including the UK. It is estimated that government-backed funds account for around $30tr (£18.5tr) of global assets, the same as the estimated $30tr of pension funds' assets. Since the beginning of 2008, which marks the high point for most stock and bond markets, funds registered with the Sovereign Wealth Fund Institute have increased their assets by 59%. Much of the gain is from oil and gas revenues, which soared after the eurozone crisis caused a wholesale price rise. webTitle: Eurostar and Keolis bid to run east coast railway line

fields.bodyText: Eurostar is entering the bidding for the east coast mainline rail franchise, as the government prepares to privatise the London-Edinburgh route before the next general election. Eurostar and Keolis, both majority-owned by the French state rail operator, SNCF, have announced a joint venture to bid for the contract. The Department for Transport (DfT) will start vetting bidders next month, with a view to restoring the line to the private sector in March 2015. The east coast franchise is currently run by a government-owned company, Directly Operated Railways (DOR). It was brought in to operate the line as East Coast after National Express defaulted on the London-Edinburgh franchise in 2009, when the transport group admitted it could not afford the £1.4bn in payments due over the life of the contract. webTitle: Shire climbs on new drug prospects and cost savings

fields.standfirst: Pharmaceutical group lifted by buy note on drug pipeline, cuts and possible acquisitions
fields.body:
Shire is among the risers in a down market, lifted by City hopes for its next range of products and cost saving announcements.

Analysts at JP Morgan Cazenove raised their recommendation on the pharmaceutical group from neutral to overweight and its price target from £22.70 to £30. They said:

Upcoming phase III newsflow could drive significant upgrades. In the first quarter of 2014 Shire will report headline data for three phase III studies, Vyvanse Depression ($1bn potential), Vyvanse Binge Eating ($0.3bn potential) and Lifitegrast for Dry Eye ($0.5bn potential). Together these three products could contribute around $2bn in annual sales, 40% of the current topline. We believe consensus reflects only around $1bn.
Cost savings announcement could offer further upside, with an update likely at third quarter 2013 results. Based on our call with the chief executive, the third quarter could see Shire discuss the potential for further selling, general and administrative savings, driven by simplification of the business and highlight the slack within R&D for 2014 and beyond, as the late-stage pipeline completes development, giving fuel for in-licensing. Acquisitions likely to be a third driver of upgrades, funded by net cash position. Shire is already net cash, we forecast a $3bn or so net cash position by the end of 2014, giving significant firepower to expand the late stage pipeline. Shire's increased Vyvanse promotion hasn't yet led to acceleration in prescriptions, however on our chief executive call Shire expressed confidence they could beat our $285m third quarter Vyvanse forecast. Following recent share-price weakness, the lack of a rebound appears appreciated.

Shire is currently up 20p at £24.87, while the FTSE 100 is down 45.63 points at 6467.03 on growing US, Italian and Greek political worries.

Among the other risers G4S - currently providing security for the Conservative party conference - has edged up 0.1p to 254p following weekend reports that an activist hedge fund, Cevian Capital, is pushing for the company to sell its cash solutions arm, which accounts for 25% of profits.

But Unilever is down 14p at £24.43 after ING said it could be affected by any negative comments about emerging markets from a Nestle investor presentation. The bank's analyst Marco Gulpers said:

In our view Nestle might update on volumes being impacted in emerging markets as consumers are being impacted by inflationary pressures (like in India where food inflation is up 18.8% since July) but also we could hear more about cost inflation spiralling related to weakening emerging market currencies trends. With Unilever seen as the emerging market play any negatives from Nestle will be seen as a negative read-across to Unilever at current valuation levels.

Elsewhere Reckitt Benckiser has edged up 1p to £45.19 despite a sell not from Liberum. It said:

The debate on Reckitt shares is more on how to value Pharmaceuticals (21% of earnings in 2012) than on the core business. Taking reasonable 11 to 12 times EBITDA multiples for the core unit implies an enterprise value for Pharmaceuticals of £6bn to £8bn which could only be justified if Pharmaceuticals' earnings grew 50%-100% in 2014 – we find that unrealistic given current competitive dynamics and recent earnings trends.

Liberum was more positive on ITV, down 1.4p at 174.4p:

Press reports out that ITV has sold the old Granada TV studios in Manchester for £26.5m subject to redevelopment planning permission. Probably not included within analyst forecasts for cashflow (it is not in ours; we have 2013 net cash of £194m) so gives ITV more flexibility if it wants to return cash.

webTitle: FTSE 100 falls on US, Italian and Greek political woes but housebuilders boosted by Help to Buy

fields.standfirst: Investors nervous about possible American government shutdown and Italian government collapse
fields.body:
With shares undermined by political chaos in the US and Europe, as well as weak Chinese data, housebuilders are proving a bright spot.

The UK government's decision to bring forward the next stage of its Help to Buy programme, a £12bn mortgage guarantee scheme to boost the housing market, has lifted Persimmon 19p to £10.80, making it the biggest riser in a falling FTSE 100. Among the mid-caps, Barratt Developments is 9p better at 311.1p. Both have also been helped by positive comments from JP Morgan Cazenove. The broker said:

The housebuilders underperformed the market by around 11% in the third quarter, impacted by worries over the scale of upside and longer-term sustainability of earnings, driven in turn by concerns over eventual interest rate increases, cost inflation and speculation that Help to Buy could be withdrawn; all of which are concerns that we believe to be misplaced. Despite taking what we view as a conservative stance on house price inflation, volume growth and cost inflation, our earnings per share estimates for 2014 and 2015 are around 25% ahead of Bloomberg consensus. We view the recent sell-off as a buying opportunity.

Not only has Help to Buy not been withdrawn, the plan which was due to start in January is now likely to begin within days. But it has caused some concern, with opponents suggesting it could fuel a new housing bubble. But that has not stopped the rise of other builders, with Bellway up 33p at £12.95 and Taylor Wimpey adding 1.85p to 98/85p.

Overall the FTSE 100 has fallen 46.62 points to 6466.04, hit by worries about a US government shutdown as politicians fail to reach agreement on the country's budget. In Italy the government is poised for a confidence vote on Wednesday after Silvio Berlusconi told his party to resign from the coalition, while in Greece the arrest of Golden Dawn members has renewed political uncertainty in the struggling country. Michael Hewson, senior market analyst at CMC Markets, said:

If investors had been hoping that common sense would prevail over the weekend, in either Italy or the US for that matter, then they would have ended up sorely disappointed. Given the protagonists involved in events either side of the Atlantic any other outcome, would probably have been wishful thinking and so it has proved.
The effect on the fragile US economy cannot be overstated as federal employees get put on temporary leave, causing drops in economic output, consumer spending, retail sales and other related economic indicators. Even if this particular pot hole is somehow avoided the thorny problem of the raising of the debt ceiling by October 17 is the next carbuncle for markets to obsess about. The small matter of the latest US employment report, due Friday, could well be the victim of any US government shutdown, though we will still get sight of the September US ADP jobs report on Wednesday for further clues about the health of the US labour market.

On top of that an HSBC manufacturing survey came in at 50.2, up from 50.1 but lower than the initial reading of 51.2. So mining shares were among the leading fallers on worries of falling demand from a key customer, with Anglo American 34.5p lower at 1505.5p and Glencore Xstrata down 7.6p at 336.4p.

webTitle: SSE predicts first-half profits below 2012 levels

fields.standfirst: Energy firm expects profit to reflect higher wholesale prices but will maintain 'discipline' during Miliband price freeze debate
fields.body:
The energy company SSE has warned that first-half profits will be lower than last year and said it would remain "disciplined" despite the fierce political debate ignited by Ed Miliband's energy price freeze pledge.

The FTSE 100 company in an update said adjusted profit before tax for the six months to 30 September was expected to be lower than the same period in 2012, reflecting higher wholesale gas prices and other costs.

SSE said it was on track to meet its target of increasing the dividend for the current year by more than retail price inflation.

Shares in SSE and other energy companies were hit last week by the Labour leader's latest policy plans, which were unveiled at the party's annual conference and would see prices frozen for 20 months to the end of 2017.

"Despite the intensifying political debate, we will maintain our operational and financial discipline, to enable us to deliver an above-inflation increase in the dividend for this financial year and beyond," said the finance director, Gregor Alexander, on Monday.

It emerged on Friday that SSE is considering plans to scale back its investment in marine and tidal power projects, putting Britain's leading role in new technology at risk.

It follows similar moves by other major energy players, and the lobby group RenewableUK warned that a difficult regulatory environment had depressed forecasts of how much capacity could be deployed and slowed the progress of the sector.

SSE said on Monday that first-half profits were likely to account for a lower proportion of full-year profits but that it "should have no implications for the full financial year".

"Despite challenging energy market conditions, SSE has made solid progress in recent months, including taking a number of specific steps to help small business customers and improve standards for household customers.

"We continue to benefit from maintaining a balanced range of energy businesses," said Alexander.

SSE will publish first-half results on 13 November.

webTitle: Housing bubble? Reserve Bank puts SMSFs under the spotlight

fields.standfirst: RBA strikes a measured tone on suggestions of overheating in the housing market, but singles out self-managed super funds
fields.body:
Last week, once again, there was a flurry of talk about a housing bubble.

This time the driver for the talk was the Financial Stability Review issued by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA). While the review suggested that the Australian financial system continued to perform "relatively well", it put a spotlight on the housing market and in particular the role of "self managed superannuation funds (SMSFs)".

With regards to suggestions of a bubble, the RBA has been pretty measured. Two weeks ago at a panel session, the financial systems assistant governor of the RBA, Malcolm Edey, noted that while housing prices have risen in recent months, it was important to "keep these things in perspective". He noted that in the past 10 years housing prices had risen similar to or on average less than the growth of household income.

This was a phenomenon I mentioned in August, but I would suggest that while the ratio of housing prices to incomes is around the level it was 10 years ago focussing only on that rather ignores the huge surge that occurred from 2000 to 2006, and the fall that occurred due to the GFC.

If we were to lengthen the scope back 15 years, the comparison is much less flat. The RBA's current focus on SMSFs is interesting because they were not a factor in the 2000-06 housing boom. Changes to legislation instituted since 2006 have given SMSFs access to the property market. Most crucially in September 2007 the Howard government legislated to allow SMSFs to "borrow money to purchase assets under limited recourse conditions (that is, in the event of borrower default, the lender only has the right to recover losses from these assets)". Prior to this, the RBA notes, "superannuation funds were not permitted to borrow money for investment, which limited the ability of SMSFs to directly invest in property."

As a result, the RBA warns that the SMSF sector "represents a vehicle for potentially speculative demand for property that did not exist in the past." And speculation is the driver of bubbles.

Housing price bubbles are especially worrying because when they burst, they place stress on the banking sector as well as on the wealth of those who had invested directly in the housing market.

The added piece to the bubble worry is that SMSFs concern people's retirement. Thus the RBA is not just worried that the increase in property investment by SMSFs "could potentially exacerbate property price cycles", but that such investments (which now account for around 15% of all SMSF assets) exposed SMSF members "to greater financial risks than they envisage".

The RBA noted that at present the SMSF sector is a "very small share of banks' loan portfolios and hence pose little risk for the financial system at this point". It also noted that some banks have already started to become "more active in the provision of advice on how to setup and manage SMSFs".

You can understand why the RBA is so concerned about the potential for a bubble in the housing market when you look at the link between Australian household wealth and debt.

In the early 2000s, household wealth boomed but it was off the back of a large increase in debt – much of it to finance property investments (included in the "non-financial assets" in the graph above). In 2000, Australia's household debt to income ratio was 93%; now it is 148%. Thus a property price crash at this time would be more damaging than back in 2000 because households are much more in debt than they were then.

At present, the RBA is playing the role of being alert but not alarmed. It noted that: "Australian households continue to show more prudence in managing their finances than a decade ago." But it does sound a note of caution, when it states, that given "household indebtedness and gearing are still around historically high levels, continued prudent saving and borrowing behaviour would help support households' ongoing financial resilience".

It also gave a pointed warning regarding both low interest rates and housing prices.

On the historically low rates, it suggested households need to be clear that risks remain and that they should "appropriately account for the financial risks they take" – notably that the rates will rise.

On housing prices it sounded a little warning bell, saying that households need to "maintain realistic expectations of future dwelling price growth" – because the market is highly unlikely to boom like it did in the early 2000s.

One person not so concerned about a possible housing price bubble is the prime minister, Tony Abbott. On Melbourne's 3AW last Friday he said: "If housing prices go up, sure that makes it harder to get into the market, but it also means that everyone who is in the market has a more valuable asset."

It recalls John Howard in 2003 saying, "For people who are already in the housing market, the increase in the value of their homes has been welcome. I don't get people stopping me in the street and saying, 'John you're outrageous, under your government the value of my house has increased'."

Howard said that in the midst of the biggest increase in household debt in Australian history – an increase which was not sustainable:

It may have increased Australian household wealth, but one hopes Tony Abbott is not seeking a return to those years.
